newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Protesters slam Kazakh president and government.
newsitem.headline: Protesters slam Kazakh president and government.

text.p: About 300 people staged a rare protest against Kazakh President Nursultan Nazarbayev and his government's economic policies on Sunday.

The protesters, mainly pensioners and communists, were angered by a backlog of unpaid wages and pensions and demanded restoration of the Soviet Union in the demonstration in the centre of the Central Asian state's capital, Almaty.

They carried banners declaring "The president must be sacked" and "Nazarbayev, your reforms are a noose around our necks". Traditional Soviet songs rang out of a makeshift loud speaker and some people waved red Soviet flags.

"Nazarbayev and his government have betrayed their people and sold 90 percent of our industries to capitalism. Down with the bourgeoisie," protester Utegen Kabaziyev, who called himself a devoted Bolshevik communist, told Reuters.
An elderly woman screamed: "We had guaranteeed food, clothes and work in Soviet times but we have nothing today."
Many people are disenchanted with the government's privatisation proramme and some have not received their wages or pensions for several months.
Leonoid Solomin, chairman of Kazakhstan's free trade unions, said combined salary and pension arrears now totalled about 100 billion tenge ($1.3 billion dollars).

But Sunday's protest was isolated, unsanctioned by the authorities and not supported by the trade unions. Nazarbayev rules with a firm hand and tolerates little dissent in the former Soviet republic of almost 17 million people.
